'''HMS ''Foxglove''''' was an {{sclass-|Acacia|sloop|0}} [[Minesweeper (ship)|minesweeping]] [[sloop-of-war|sloop]] of the [[Royal Navy]]. She saw service in [[World War I]] and [[World War II]].
==Construction== ''Foxglove'' was built at [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]], by [[Barclay Curle]] and launched on 30 March 1915.<ref name=Colledge>Colledge, p. 142.</ref><ref name="Conway's All The World p. 94">''Conway's All The World's Fighting Ships 1906-1921'', p. 94.</ref> She entered service later that year.
==World War I== During World War I, ''Foxglove'' and the other ''Acacia''-class sloops were used almost exclusively for [[minesweeping]] duties until 1917, when the Royal Navy began to use them as [[convoy]] escorts, a task to which they were well suited.<ref name="Conway's All The World p. 94"/>
==Interwar== ''Foxglove'' served on the [[China Station]] during the early 1920s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naval-history.net/Oxon01-ShipList.htm |publisher=naval-history.net |title=Royal Navy Log Books of the World War 1 Era - An Old Weather Citizen History Project |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref>
On the evening of 3 March 1921, the [[Singapore|Singaporean]] [[passenger ship]] {{SS|Hong Moh}} grounded on the White Rocks off Lamock Island, [[Shantou|Swatow]], [[China]], and was wrecked with the loss of an estimated 900 to 1,000 lives. The [[Steamship|steamer]] {{SS|Shanti}} discovered the wreck on the morning of 4 March and rendered assistance, rescuing 45 survivors before steaming to Swatow to seek additional help for ''Hong Moh''. Upon receiving word of the disaster, the British consul at Swatow informed the British Senior Naval Officer at [[Hong Kong]], who in turn broadcast a wireless message requesting ships to come to ''Hong Moh''′s aid. ''Foxglove'' arrived on the scene late on 5 March but was unable to locate the wreck in the darkness. The Royal Navy [[light cruiser]] {{HMS|Carlisle|D67|6}} joined ''Foxglove'' on the scene at dawn on 6 March, and the two ships located ''Hong Moh'' and began to rescue additional survivors, with ''Foxglove'' taking 28 or 48 (sources differ) survivors on board before having to depart late in the afternoon to refuel. ''Carlisle'' remained on the scene until 8 March, leaving only when there was no further sign of life board the wreck of ''Hong Moh''; she then proceeded to Hong Kong with 221 survivors aboard.<ref name="hkgro">{{cite journal | url=http://hkgro.lib.hku.hk/archive/files/29d0e2aca1eda16021b27af745e92a08.pdf | title=Findings of the Marine Court of Inquiry | journal=[[Hong Kong Government Gazette]] | date=27 May 1921 | pages=226–227}}</ref><ref>[http://www.maritime-connector.com/ContentDetails/1491/gcgid/193/lang/English/Passenger-ship-incidents.wshtml Maritime Connector: Passenger Ship Incidents] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100924083247/http://www.maritime-connector.com/ContentDetails/1491/gcgid/193/lang/English/Passenger-ship-incidents.wshtml |date=September 24, 2010 }}</ref>
==World War II== ''Foxglove'' was one of only two ''Acacia''-class sloops to survive long enough to see service in World War II.<ref name="Conway's All The World p. 94"/> She became a loss when she was [[dive bomber|dive-bombed]] and badly damaged by German aircraft off the [[Isle of Wight]] on 9 July 1940. She remained afloat, and was converted into an [[accommodation ship]] and base ship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/viewship.asp?id=4295 |publisher=Clydebuilt Database Shipping Times |title=HMS Foxglove |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref> In this new role, she became a harbour [[guard ship]] in 1941,<ref name=Colledge/> serving at Londonderry (also known as [[Derry]]) in [[Northern Ireland]] for the remainder of World War II.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/northernireland/radiofoyle/peoples_war/context.shtml |title=Radio Foyle People's War |work=BBC Radio |accessdate=3 May 2015}}</ref>
==Fate== The last surviving ''Acacia''-class sloop,<ref name="Conway's All The World p. 94"/> ''Foxglove'' was sold for scrapping on 7 September 1946. She was scrapped at [[Troon]], Scotland.<ref name=Colledge/>
==Legacy== ''Foxglove''{{'}}s [[logbook]] is among those that was selected for digitisation as part of the online [[Old Weather]] project.<ref>[http://www.oldweather.org/ Old Weather]</ref>
